text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service
This transmits revised IRM 9.7.5, Forms, Processing, and Documentation.

Subsection 9.7.5.2 is revised to reflect that the Asset Forfeiture Tracking and Retrieval (AFTRAK) system number is no longer issued by Headquarters. The AFTRAK database assigns numbers to seizures and to assets.
Subsection 9.7.5.4 is revised to indicate that the AFTRAK system is a web-based application. The subsection is further updated to indicate how the data is input and managed.

Subsection 9.7.5.4.1 is revised to state that the AFTRAK database assigns numbers to seizures to assets. The subsection is further updated to indicate an additional seizure number must be obtained when over 99 assets are associated with one seizure number.
Former subsection 9.7.5.4.2 is deleted due to Form 4008, Seized Property Report, being obsolete; all references to Form 4008 have been removed. All subsequent subsections are renumbered sequentially.
Position titles have been updated throughout the section to reflect the new organizational titles that were effective with the October 1, 2011, reorganization of Criminal Investigation.
revisions, deletions, and grammatical changes were made throughout the section, which not result in substantive changes but contributed to procedural clarity of the subject matter.

) This section covers the when, why, how and importance of the accurate and timely tracking of seizure investigations and seized assets. (

) Seizures are assigned two separate numbers as they are tracked on two separate systems, the Criminal Investigation Management Information the Seizure (CIMIS) and the Asset Forfeiture Tracking and Retrieval System (AFTRAK). (The CIMIS number, either a primary investigation (PI) or subject criminal in- vestigation (SCI) with approved seizure activity, tracks time expended on the seizure investigation). The AFTRAK number tracks a specific asset from the date of seizure through the forfeiture and/or disposition process. The database assigns numbers to seizures and to assets (See subsection

) The CIMIS database tracks the status and progress of criminal investigations and the time expended by special agents. It is used as a management tool that provides the basis for decisions of both local and national scope, see Information Chapters
, Criminal Investigation Management Information System. (

) When asset forfeiture is anticipated in an investigation, a special agent must obtain seizure investigation activity authority. This is done by indicating in Seizures CIMIS that seizure activity is anticipated in the PI or SCI. Seizure Activity activity authorization must be obtained for any seizure investigation in which Criminal Investigation (CI) participates, even if the lead agency is another Federal, state, or local law enforcement agency, or foreign country. (
) Authorized seizure activity should be initiated for each specific target of a seizure investigation, and not for each asset that may be subject to (
) The authority to conduct seizure investigative activities on an authorized tigation is delegated to special agents by the Special Agent in Charge pursuant to Delegation Order

)). This approval authority cannot be re-delegated. By authorizing seizure gative activities on an authorized investigation (PI or SCI) in the CIMIS database, the SAC delegates his/her authority to conduct seizure activities to special agents. (
) Seizure investigative activities cannot be authorized without an underlining or SCI. (

) All time expended in connection with the seizure and forfeiture, including spent identifying and locating assets and their ownership, writing affidavits, consulting with a Criminal Tax Attorney or the Assistant US Attorney, preparing for, and executing seizure warrants, preparing seizure forms and reports, investigating claims and petitions, and participating as necessary through the conclusion of the forfeiture and disposition of the asset(s), be charged to the corresponding PI or SCI. (

) The Asset Forfeiture Coordinator’s (AFC) time spent on seizure should be charged to the corresponding PI or SCI. The AFC time spent inventories, reconciliations, and other administrative work relating to seizure investigations should be charged to an asset forfeiture general gation (GI). (

This section covers the when, why, how and importance of the accurate and timely tracking of seizure investigations and seized assets.

Seizures are assigned two separate numbers as they are tracked on two separate systems, the Criminal Investigation Management Information System (CIMIS) and the Asset Forfeiture Tracking and Retrieval System (AFTRAK). (The CIMIS number, either a primary investigation (PI) or subject criminal in- vestigation (SCI) with approved seizure activity, tracks time expended on the seizure investigation). The AFTRAK number tracks a specific asset from the date of seizure through the forfeiture and/or disposition process. The AFTRAK database assigns numbers to seizures and to assets (See subsection

When asset forfeiture is anticipated in an investigation, a special agent obtain seizure investigation activity authority. This is done by indicating in CIMIS that seizure activity is anticipated in the PI or SCI. Seizure activity authorization must be obtained for any seizure investigation in Criminal Investigation (CI) participates, even if the lead agency is another Federal, state, or local law enforcement agency, or foreign country. )). This approval authority cannot be re-delegated. By authorizing seizure gative activities on an authorized investigation (PI or SCI) in the CIMIS database, the SAC delegates his/her authority to conduct seizure activities to special agents. Seizure investigative activities cannot be authorized without an underlining or SCI. All time expended in connection with the seizure and forfeiture, including spent identifying and locating assets and their ownership, writing affidavits, consulting with a Criminal Tax Attorney or the Assistant US Attorney, preparing for, and executing seizure warrants, preparing seizure forms and reports, investigating claims and petitions, and participating as necessary through the conclusion of the forfeiture and disposition of the asset(s), be charged to the corresponding PI or SCI. The Asset Forfeiture Coordinator’s (AFC) time spent on seizure should be charged to the corresponding PI or SCI. The AFC time spent inventories, reconciliations, and other administrative work relating to seizure investigations should be charged to an asset forfeiture general gation (GI).

When asset forfeiture is anticipated in an investigation, a special agent must obtain seizure investigation activity authority. This is done by indicating in CIMIS that seizure activity is anticipated in the PI or SCI. Seizure investigation activity authorization must be obtained for any seizure investigation in which Criminal Investigation (CI) participates, even if the lead agency is another Federal, state, or local law enforcement agency, or foreign country.
Authorized seizure activity should be initiated for each specific target of a seizure investigation, and not for each asset that may be subject to

The authority to conduct seizure investigative activities on an authorized tigation is delegated to special agents by the Special Agent in Charge (SAC), pursuant to Delegation Order 9-2 (Formerly Delegation Order 158 (Rev. 2)). This approval authority cannot be re-delegated. By authorizing seizure gative activities on an authorized investigation (PI or SCI) in the CIMIS database, the SAC delegates his/her authority to conduct seizure activities to special agents.

) The standard format for an AFTRAK number is an eight-digit seizure plus a two-digit asset number. When over

assets are associated with seizure number, an additional seizure number must be obtained. This must be followed when providing a CI agency seizure (AFTRAK) number national seized property contractor. (

) Multiple assets seized on the same day, from the same location, and the same individual(s) can be tracked under one AFTRAK number. A AFTRAK number must be obtained for assets seized on different days, at different locations, or from different owners at the same location.

assets are associated with one seizure number, an additional seizure number must be obtained. This format must be followed when providing a CI agency seizure (AFTRAK) number to a national seized property contractor. (

) Multiple assets seized on the same day, from the same location, and owned the same individual(s) can be tracked under one AFTRAK number. A separate AFTRAK number must be obtained for assets seized on different days, at different locations, or from different owners at the same location.

) The AFTRAK system and processing procedures associated with AFTRAK continue to change. The current forms and procedures can be located on Connections in the Warrants and Forfeiture web site. (

) The AFC is responsible for the accuracy and timeliness of information in AFTRAK for his/her field office. The AFC will be held accountable for ancies between the status of an asset and the information on AFTRAK. Retrieval (
) The AFC should periodically check the information on AFTRAK by the various AFTRAK reports available. Errors on AFTRAK should be re- searched and corrected. (

) The Secretary of the Treasury is required by statute to submit certain to Congress each year concerning the Treasury Forfeiture Fund (TFF). Congress the reports required are a complete set of audited financial statements for TFF (including a balance sheet, income statement, and cash flow analysis are subject to annual financial audits). (

) Other required reports include an analysis of income and expenses the revenue received or lost by property category (such as general vehicles, vessels, aircraft, cash, and real property) and by type of (such as sale, remission, cancellation, or placement into official use, with state and local agencies, and destruction). (

) In order to prepare the reports to Congress, the Treasury Executive Office Asset Forfeiture (TEOAF) must compile information from the law agencies and the US Coast Guard participating in the TFF, including CI. (
) The IRS is also required by statute to prepare and submit to Congress Office of Management and Budget, audited financial statements for each year. (
) The information provided by CI to TEOAF and the IRS to prepare the statements and other reports to Congress comes from AFTRAK. is imperative that AFTRAK contain accurate and timely information. (

) Criminal Investigation conducts a one hundred percent physical inventory seized assets each mid-year and fiscal year end. The inventory is Fiscal Year to insure the reliability of AFTRAK and the field office databases. The Financial Officers Act of
requires that a physical inventory be to ensure the accuracy of the information used in the financial statements prepared for both IRS and the TFF. (
) The process of preparing the financial statements begins with the field performing their inventories. The AFC is responsible for the physical of all seized assets. (
) Prior to March
and September
of each year, Warrants and send a memorandum with detailed inventory instructions to all SACs and AFCs.

Asset Seizure and (

) The accurate and timely preparation, review, and processing of seizure forfeiture forms, memoranda, and correspondence is the responsibility of AFC. However, these duties are authorized for and generally performed by AFS with oversight from the AFC. (
) Electronic versions of all the seizure and forfeiture forms discussed are exhibited in IRM Chapter
, Asset Seizure and Forfeiture, and available CI Connections in the Warrants and Forfeiture web site. (
) Samples of letters, notices, claim forms and memoranda are discussed exhibited in IRM Chapter
, Asset Seizure and Forfeiture, and on CI tions in the Warrants and Forfeiture web site. (
) Processing procedures are contained in IRM Chapter
, Asset Seizure Forfeiture. Processing procedures are also in TEOAF Directives, guides policy memoranda on CI Connections in the Warrants and Forfeiture web (

) The AFC will establish and maintain a seizure/forfeiture file for each separate from any investigative file. The seizure/forfeiture files are subject the same records retention and management requirements as investigative files, see IRM
, Records Control Schedule for CI. (
) The AFS’s primary duties include documentation and maintenance of the zure/forfeiture files with oversight from the AFC. (

) The seizure/forfeiture file must contain the required forms and sufficient mation to document and support the actions in the seizure and forfeiture process from pre-seizure through final disposition and equitable sharing. (
) Most field offices use some type of a checklist, cover or control sheet to ensure the seizure/forfeiture file is properly documented and maintained.

Processing procedures are contained in IRM Chapter 9.7, Asset Seizure and Forfeiture. Processing procedures are also in TEOAF Directives, guides and policy memoranda on CI Connections in the Warrants and Forfeiture web site.
